citation.article-title: Mycoplasma oxoniensis, a new species isolated from Chinese hamster conjunctivas.

p.s: Description of Mycoplasma oxoniensis sp. nov.
Mycoplasma oxoniensis (ox.on.i.en'si.s. M. L. gen. oxoniensis, pertaining to Oxon, an abbreviation of Oxfordshire, where the mycoplasmas were isolated)
Habitat. M. oxoniensis occurs in Chinese hamster conjunctivas.
Pleomorphic cells bounded by a single unit membrane.
Colonies on agar have a typical fried egg appearance.
Organisms are filterable through 300-nm-pore-size membrane filters and are resistant to penicillin.
The DNA base composition is 29 mol% guanine plus cytosine.
Requires sterol (inhibited by digitonin and sodium polyanethol sulfonate).
Optimal growth occurs at 35 to 37Â°C under either aerobic or anaerobic conditions.
Glucose, mannose, maltose, and sucrose are metabolized; arginine, urea, and esculin are not hydrolyzed.
Methylene blue and tellurite (anaerobically) are reduced but resazurin and tetrazolium are not; phosphatase is produced.
Serologically distinct from all other Mycoplasma species.
The type strain is strain 128 (= NCTC 11712).
